FacilityName: US Energy Partners, LLC Ethanol Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
US ENERGY PARTNERS ETHANOL PLANT 
US ENERGY PARTNERS ASSOCIATES, LLC, RUSSELL, KANSAS

Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

US Energy Partners Associates, LLC has a commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel as well as considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility.

US Energy Partners? policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain and control the release, as necessary.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The US Energy Partners Ethanol Plant is located in the City of Russell, Russell County, Kansas.

The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol from corn.  The only substance regulated under the RMP Program is denaturant, which contains regulated flammable chemicals such as propane, isopentane, and butane.  US Energy Partners has evaluated denaturants from several suppliers with the RMP Comp program and determined that the radius of impact from a worst-case release remains the same.  This is due primarily to the fact that available denaturants are fairly similar in composition.  As such, this RMP is submitted to cover any denaturant stored at the facility, regardless of the supplier.

Off-site Consequence Analysis Results

The worst-case scenario at the facility is the release of denaturant stored in a 39,000 gallon aboveground storage tank followed by ignition of the resulting vapor cloud. The worst-case scenario is based on the release of a full tank (39,000 gallons). The worst-case vapor cloud explosion generates a 1 psig over-pressure endpoint approximately 0.4 miles from the center of the plant. There are no public receptors, environmental rece

ptors, or population centers within this distance. 

Although US Energy Partners has numerous controls in place to prevent such a release and to manage potential consequences, no credit for administrative controls or passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this scenario.

Since the facility qualifies as a Program Level I, no Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) was required. 

Five Year Accident History

US Energy Partners Associates, LLC is currently constructing the ethanol facility and startup is expected on October 22, 2001.  As such, there have been no onsite or offsite accidents, as defined by EPA?s General Guidance on Risk Management Programs during US Energy Partners? ownership.

Emergency Response Program Information

The US Energy Partners Ethanol Plant has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including a Health & Safety Plan.  The facility is currently complying with standards under 40 CFR 112.  A Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure Plan (SPCC) will be prepared and implemented in accordance with applicable regulatory standards and timeframes.  

The facility also conducts employee training as part of facility activities.  US Energy Partners? corporate policy places the utmost importance on worker, public and environmental safety, which is reflected in facility plans and training activities.

A safety inspection and a review of the facility?s emergency response plan is pending facility start-up.
